abstracts.cdata!:
The North China Plain is one of the most
            densely populated regions in the world, encompassing the
            capital Beijing, many other important industrial cities, and
            on the coastal edge, commercial ports. It covers about 400km
            and is China's main agricultural region. The soil of
            the North China Plain is fertile, but water scarcity is a
            growing problem. In many areas, increasing agricultural
            demands can no longer be met by adding hydraulic
            infrastructure such as storage reservoirs, and groundwater
            is over-exploited. Water supplies to agriculture are under
            mounting stress from competing demands for municipal and
            industrial uses. The problem of water scarcity is compounded
            by worsening water pollution from heavy industrialization
            and rapid urban population growth. It is increasingly
            realized that future growth in agricultural water demand can
            only partly be covered by the additional development of
            water resources or possibly by costly water transfer
            projects that would bring water from the relatively
            water-rich south to the north. The remaining demand will
            need to be met through water savings, demand management, and
            deficit irrigation.
